Forum Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street Manhattan Through March 1

A formidable assemblage of faces has been gathered for this ambitious portrait jam, organized by Townsend Wolfe, former director and chief curator of the Arkansas Art Center in Little Rock. The subjects range from a demure but vivid young thing known as ''Mady'' (1948), by Alice Neel, to the belligerent, what's-it-to-you countenance of the painter Francesco Clemente, seen in a woodcut he did in 1982.

In between are close to 60 others, some quirky and antic like Red Grooms's 1980 version of Salvador Dal√≠, a dimensional print with Ping- Pong balls for eyes; others ultra-traditional, like the amazingly realistic rendition of an unknown bluestocking done in 1918 by Mark Tobey, known now only for his calligraphic abstractions. A pastiche that may put you in mind of ''The Sopranos'' is Kent Bellows's 2000 canvas ''Self-Portrait With Wine Glass (Gluttony),'' in which the artist wallows in a Lucullan feast borrowed from old master still lifes.

Literati are present in Bernard Perlin's silverpoint drawing of the reticent E. M. Forster (1947) and in an undated ink-on-paper impression of a dour James Joyce by Pavel Tchelitchew. Political powerhouses are paraded here, too, with Ben Shahn's gouache of Josef Goebbels caught in full rant and Robert Arneson's 1991 portrait on paper of the first President Bush, titled ''Most Evil No. 2,'' in which the president is quite as mockingly observed.
In short, dull moments are few and far between in this engrossing show, which more than occasionally goes beyond the facts of its faces to real insights.
